question: Poet Henry David Thoreau once wrote, "I cannot make my days longer, so I strive to make them better." I spoke with freshman Eliza Ramirez, who told me how alienated she feels from her own homeroom. I spoke with sophomore Reggie Banks, who said his mother works in a cafeteria and can't afford to buy him enough spiral notebooks for his classes. I won't bore you with long- winded promises about all the new and innovative things I will definitely achieve during the year in which it will be my honor and privilege to represent each and every one of you, but I can say that my years of experience on the student council have taught me the three most important attributes the president needs to possess; commitment -

answer: Wow! Mr. McAllister! This is so wild. We came to celebrate my victory, and I can't believe it. Here, these are my parents. This is great.

question: You bet.
answer: So, Mr. M, I was starting to think about ideas for next year. I was thinking it would be cool to have, like a carnival. With rides. And, you know, it could be for, like. Muscular Dystrophy. And on Halloween we could have a haunted house. But a really good haunted house, not like those cheesy bad ones. You know, more like the radio station ones. This one would be really scary. And for Homecoming -- well, you know how last year's theme was -

question: Paul... Paul.... We'll have plenty of time to get into all this later. A whole year, in fact. Right now I just need to finish my pie and get home.
answer: Oh, okay. Yeah, sorry. Just one more thing. So, Mr. M., uh, do you think Tracy's going to be okay? I saw her face after the assembly, and I think she's taking it pretty hard.

question: Senior year was very productive for me and full of personal achievement. Order. Order. Order I Can we vote on this? Those in favor. On top of a very successful student council year, I got into Cornell like I wanted, with scholarships, and I was in the top 7th percentile of my graduating class. But sometimes I got lonely, and I'd think about Dave. I missed our talks. Maybe it could have worked out between us. I don't know. I wonder what he's doing now. Maybe he finally finished his novel When the yearbooks came out, I was on almost every page. Paul, will you sign my yearbook?
answer: Sure, Tracy.

question: Can I sign yours too?
answer: Oh, yeah, sure. Hey Nolan, give my book to Tracy when you're done*

question: I thought very carefully about what to write. Because despite everything that had happened with the election, I really wished him well. I even signed it...
answer: Thanks, Tracy. Hey, Tracy I..

question: Yes, Paul?
answer: Have a great summer. And good luck at college.
